title.rendered: Video game store itch.io calls NFTs a ‘scam’

content.rendered:
Independent video game online store itch.io took a stance on the NFT craze, calling it nothing more or less than “a scam.”

A few have asked about our stance on NFTs:

NFTs are a scam. If you think they are legitimately useful for anything other than the exploitation of creators, financial scams, and the destruction of the planet we ask that please reevaluate your life choices.

Peace ✌️

— itch.io (@itchio) February 6, 2022

“Some have asked where we stand on NFTs, well, they are a scam. And if you believe that they are legitimately useful for something other than the exploitation of creatives, financial scams or the destruction of the planet, then we ask you to re-evaluate your life decisions, ”he shot on his social media profile.

Itch.io is an online video game store for PC that claims to differentiate itself in its royalty payment practices from the giant and benchmark Steam. However, to achieve that goal, it only offers independent titles, several of them exclusive to itch.io. The platform also hosts game jams, marathons in which a group of developers create a video game from scratch.

Non fungible tokens (NFT) are a kind of digital certificates that validate the uniqueness of a digital asset. This format has generated great enthusiasm in a sector of Internet consumers and even has the support of personalities such as Jack Dorsey, founder of Twitter, a self-confessed enthusiast of crypto technology.

The format has also caught the attention of some of the big video game companies, including Ubisoft, which began to include them in some of its products. Other companies, such as Atari, lent their name to use NFTs in a kind of digital raffle.

NFTs have also been used in other areas of culture. Recently, the Coachella festival put lifetime passes for its famous festival on sale in NFT format, which although they were sold at a price close to $10,000 dollars (they quintupled their price in a matter of hours).

Despite the enthusiasm, it seems that the video game industry, from its consumers to its creators, is reluctant to adopt a technology that, like cryptocurrencies themselves, faces criticism for its high electricity consumption and potential damage to the environment.
